title: Argentina orders HSBC to replace CEO in country
text:

Wed, Sep 2, 2015, 00:33 BST - UK Markets open in 7 hrs 27 mins Argentina orders HSBC to replace CEO in country By Reuters | Telegraph â€“ 1 hour 15 minutes ago 0.00 
Argentina's central bank accuses HSBC of failing to prevent tax evasion and money laundering 
Argentina's central bank has ordered HSBC to name a new chief executive for the country, accusing the bank of failing to establish necessary controls to prevent tax evasion and money laundering. 
Argentine authorities clashed with HSBC in November when they charged the lender with helping more than 4,000 clients evade taxes by stashing their money in secret Swiss bank accounts. 
HSBC rejected the charge, but Argentina said in March it wanted HSBC to repatriate $3.5bn that Argentine tax authorities claimed the bank had moved offshore. 
The central bank said on Tuesday that HSBC's chief executive and president in the country, Gabriel Martino, "had not directed the necessary measures to mitigate and adequately address the prevention of money laundering and the financing of terrorist activities". 
Officials at HSBC were not immediately available to comment to Reuters. HSBC has consistently said it respected Argentine law. 
Ricardo Echegaray, head of Argentina's AFIP tax agency, called the central bank's move "positive". He said the bank's clients who had moved money abroad through secret channels should accept criminal liability and pay the taxes owed. 
"They will have to recognize that together with Martino, and the HSBC authorities here in Argentina, they looked to cheat Argentina, to move funds abroad that they had never declared and on which they had never paid taxes," Mr Echegaray told a news conference. 
Argentina's central bank has the authority to revoke the licences of officials who legally represent commercial banks before the financial regulator. 
Europe's largest bank faces probes in several countries of allegations it helped clients dodge taxes (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
